title: Boris Johnson faces ‘midnight deadline’ to present Brexit proposal
text:
Boris Johnson was reportedly given to the end of today by Michel Barnier to present a legal text (Picture: PA/EPA)

Downing Street has declined to acknowledge a midnight deadline reportedly set by the European Union for a legal text to be produced to seal a Brexit deal.

The EU’s chief negotiator Michel Barnier says he needs good intentions to turn into a substantial document as Boris Johnson races against the clock to secure a fresh agreement.

Eager for proposals to be ready for a two day European leader’s summit starting in Brussels on Thursday, Barnier reportedly set an ultimatum for the end of the day.

When asked if Johnson recognises the deadline, the prime minister’s official spokesman said: ‘We are working hard. The prime minister is aware of the time constraints that we are under.

‘We want to make progress towards securing a deal as soon as possible and we want to make progress ahead of the EU council on Thursday.’

Barnier say he wants ‘good intentions’ to be turned into ‘legal text’ (Picture: AP)

Barnier struck a positive note after meeting Brexit Secretary Stephen Barclay at the General Affairs Council on Tuesday morning.

After debriefing the EU27 ministers in Luxembourg, he tweeted: ‘Talks are difficult but I believe an agreement is still possible.’

Earlier in the morning he said it is ‘high time to turn good intentions into a legal text’.

Arriving at the council, Barclay, who also met with Ireland’s deputy premier Simon Coveney, said: ‘The talks are ongoing. We need to give them space to proceed.

‘But detailed conversations are under way and a deal is still very possible.’

It comes as negotiators have stepped up efforts to work out how to break the deadlock over the Irish backstop, a contingency measure to prevent a hard border on the island.

Irish Foreign Minister Simon Coveney says now is not the time for ‘optimism or pessimism’ (Picture: PA)

Irish broadcaster RTE reported that two sources confirmed British negotiators will bring forward an updated plan on Tuesday to deal with the issue of customs and the Irish border.

Stressing that it is not a time for ‘optimism or pessimism’ Coveney said negotiators have ‘made progress but it’s been slow’.

He said it is a matter for negotiating teams to get the legal text in place.

Coveney added: ‘We are not putting any deadlines on these discussions. It’s possible to move beyond the summit and continue talks next week.’

Meanwhile, Downing Street said Johnson told French president Emmanuel Macron in a phone call that UK officials would ‘continue to work hard’ on securing a Brexit deal.

Advertisement

A Cabinet briefing on Brexit was postponed by the PM as negotiators continue talks to hammer out a new agreement ahead of the October 31 deadline.

Johnson is racing to secure a deal ahead of a special sitting of House of Commons on Saturday (Picture: Getty Images)

Today’s planned update to senior ministers was said to have been delayed until tomorrow so Johnson can give more detailed information on progress.

The prime minister is under mounting pressure to concede greater ground to Brussels.

Reports suggest the UK has dropped a demand that any deal must include a veto on customs arrangements for Northern Ireland’s regional assembly of Stormont.

The impending EU summit is crucial because the PM will have to get any new deal approved by MPs by Saturday if he is to avoid a clash over asking for a Brexit delay.

The Benn Act, passed by MPs opposing a no-deal, requires Johnson to ask for an extension of Article 50 if Parliament does not back a deal by then.

But the PM has repeatedly ruled this out and has pledged to get Brexit done by Halloween, ‘do or die’, regardless of the law.

Barnier says talks have been difficult but that a deal is ‘still possible’ (Picture: EPA)

Leader of the Commons Jacob Rees-Mogg has suggested the Government could use European law to achieve a no deal Brexit.

Meanwhile the Labour Party has threatened court action to force the PM to obey the legislation.

Regardless of the outcome in Brussels, a showdown is anticipated in an emergency sitting of Parliament on Saturday – the first in 37 years.

They will be able to back or reject any deal presented to them, or there will be discussions on what to do next in the Brexit saga.

description: Downing Street has decline to acknowledge a midnight deadline for a legal Brexit text set by the EU's chief negotiator Michel Barnier.
